column4: firstly, fsck-ing a disk is not something to take lightly, secondly, why do you want to fsck a disk:
fsck is not the tool for the job -- you need something like smarttools to check the disk for errors
bkar - All i have write now is a root shell and no internet access
bkar - i was going to alt install so i can fix a "moniter out of range" error i have trying to boot any kind of x
what OS/Distro are you running to have the root shell up?
bkar - 'cd dev' then 'ls' gives me ... hda hda1 hda2 hdc hdd ...
in the shell - does  this command bring up anything -- man testdisk ?
- manual is there
ok, if you encounter problems with partitioning the disk -- you can use testdisk to check the disk
so just 'testdisk' in a shell
- how would i get out of the manual
press q  or ctrl+x
press q  or ctrl+c * sorry
- "teskdisk: error while loading shared libraries: libntfs.so.9: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
it looks like a partition is ntfs and testdisk doesnt fully have support for ntfs built in
force mount -- mount -t ntfs /dev/hdXX /mountpoint -o force
you can just delete the partition to the same effect
unless you want to backup files on that partition
- wipe it all for all i care
